Americans are not wholly ded-
icated to home-cooked meals.
One-fourth of funds spent for
food in this country is spent in
restaurants.

legal OulPOSlS W give Oll-ulS
spot assistance to those arrested
in civil rights cases will soon
be established in Atlanta, Geor-
gia.


The project has been made
possible by the NAACP Legal De-
tense and Educational Fund with
the financial aid of the United
Presbyterian Commission on Re-
ligion and Race.


The Rev. Gayraud S. Wilmore,
r., the commission executive
director, presented a check for
$4,000 to Jack Greenberg, di-
rector-counsel of the Legal De-
tense and Educational Fund.


"Our commitment to this new
program is but another tangible
expression that our church be-
lieves that the Gospel demands
equal justice before the law for
ALL" Mr.. Wilmore said. ITO
believe less would be to be un-
faithful to Him whom we con-
TESS to be Lord of ALL"


Mr.. Greenberg said the illegal
outpost program will make it
possible to retain a full-time
attorney in Atlanta, who will be
able to move into even other
areas of the South and represent
defendants in civil rights cases.


The initial phase of the pro-
gram also calls for the acquisi-
ton of Federal law library
and the rental of office space.


eve do not know of single
Negro lawyer in the South who
possesses a complete library on
Federal law" Mr.. Greenberg
noted. "Once these books have
been purchased, we intend to keep
the library up-to-date."


The urgency of the project
grew out of recognition that
civil rights law has now become
an intricate specially and that
legal activity in the field has
mushroomed in the last decade,
Greenberg said.


Until now, the Legal Defense
and Educational Fund has been
aided by some 100" Cooperating
lawyers in the defense of more
than 10000 persons arrested in
demonstrations against segrega-
ton and discrimination in 1868
alone, he said.


However, he added, it has be-
come apparent that there is a
need for on the scene attorneys
to assist those involved in direct
action movements and in the
overall racial struggle as it
involves more and more local
communities.


"Almost no white lawyers in
the South can or will take civil
rights cases." he said. "while
we are fortunate that sub
stantial number of very highly
qualified Negro lawyers have
consistently worked with us over
the years, there is nevertheless
a marked shortage willing and
able to handle civil rights cases
in the South


Earlier, the nations 81 mil
lion United Presbyterians we're
asked to contribute to special
fund to aid the victims of the
struggle for racial Justice.


A minimum of $500, 900 is be-
ing sought through special Of
fering in the denomination S 5000
churches. A portion of the funds
will be used to provide bail
money for those arrested in civil
rights demonstrations and to
meet the cost of legal aid for
such persons.


Plans are to establish other
illegal outposts'' in other crucial
areas of the South as funds and

full articles.headline:
LEGAL OUTPOST


PROJECT STARTED
